awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Turning Uncertainty into Advantage: Novel Policies that Exploit Randomness of Lead Times in Supply Chains
awd_abstract_narration:
As environmental, political and business risks motivate companies to diversify their supply sources, and technology progress makes distributed networks of suppliers competitive, randomness in lead times remains an important and challenging issue in inventory management.  Contrary to prevailing wisdom that variability degrades the performance of inventory management strategies, very early evidence suggests that lead-time variability can, in certain cases, be used to advantage to produce strategies that reduce overall cost of inventory.   This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will provide further experimental evidence for understanding whether and how lead time uncertainty can be exploited to reduce inventory costs. The project will investigate how distributional information and variability in lead-time and demand patterns may yield new insights into adaptive approaches to inventory management that can dynamically adjust to changes in lead times.  

This project will thoroughly investigate the premise that variability can be effectively exploited in an adaptive fashion to develop data-driven algorithms that identify strategies to reduce overall cost of inventory. This stands in contrast with the vast majority of inventory literature, which is focused on explicit analytical methods that require assumptions on the (stationary) distribution of lead time and demand. These assumptions are often not supported in realistic inventory management scenarios.  This project examines realistic and general model settings, with the goal of identifying the key factors affecting the performance of new policies and quantifying this performance. While still very preliminary and experimental, the results of this project are expected to lead to testable hypotheses that could potentially have great implications for inventory theory and application and therefore broad practical effect.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addresses inventory control (supply chain) systems with lead times being random. These are classical models, extensively studied in inventory control literature, and having several other important applications as well. Recent previous work by the PIs yielded a surprising insight that lead time randomness can be exploited to achieve dramatic system performance improvements, compared with the cases with constant lead time. In other words, randomness of lead times can be converted from an impairment to an efficiency improvement factor. This has required a sharp departure from the common principles of the inventory policy design, such as constant-base-stock. The main outcomes and findings of his project are: 

1. The performance benefits of the lead time variability are indeed significant, not only in theory, but they are achievable under lead time distributions occurring in practice and under a broad range of system assumptions.

2. The larger the lead time variability, the larger the performance benefits of the algorithms exploiting this variability, compared to the case of constant lead time. 

3. We developed, analyzed, and tested specific algorithms, realizing benefits of the lead time randomness. 

4. In particular, we created a realistic model of an inventory system, mimicking real-world scenarios. The model includes, for example, the following features: lead time consists of multiple stages (including different transportation legs), partial lead time information is revealed in real-time, orders placed in batches, etc.; the model also includes "crisis mode" for different stages, when the lead time distribution of a stage changes over time. We showed that in this situation, the algorithm (PIPELINE) that makes more use of real-time information, even in a simplistic way, can perform much better than its alternatives. 

5. A paper, describing the project results, is under review in a journal and is publicly available. All simulation codes are publicly available and can be used by other researchers and/or practitioners.

We expect this project to serve as a first step of the new line of research that will substantially extend the state of the art on the modeling and analysis of inventory systems.

Inventory control strongly affects many sectors of US economy. A random sampling of SEC annual filings shows that companies across different industries (Apple, Amazon, GE, etc.) believe that their operating results and growth rates depend heavily on their ability of optimizing inventory management.  While large companies have been investing in novel techniques and infrastructures to build cutting-edge supply chains, incentive dictates that their explorations are specific to companies' own business models and findings are for private use. Businesses of moderate or small sizes face same problems, but typically do not have resources for similar efforts, thus relies on public knowledge on this subject to level the playing field and gaining competitiveness. This project delivers a new approach to help these firms to survive and thrive in an environment with high lead time uncertainties.

The research on lead time randomness is particularly important for the current times and a foreseeable future when companies diversify their supply sources to combat environmental, political, and business risks, and to adapt to changes of manufacturing strategies. This project helps to understand global impacts on supply chain networks as individual firms explore new strategies to accommodate lead time uncertainty for their own benefits.  The project findings and developed specific algorithms may also apply to non-business activities such as emergency management and humanitarian operations, which often encounter high delivery time uncertainties. 

The project has provided opportunities of training graduate students to carry out advanced research on supply chain management. The student participant has started her professional career with a supply chain optimization company after completing her master thesis based on her work in this project. Algorithms and simulations developed can be used as teaching materials in college classes of supply chain management, and as technical tools to assist undergraduate students in industrial engineering with their senior design projects.
